notes: Ambuehl, Bernheim & Lusardi, 'Evaluating Deliberative Competence'. Two online RCTs studying whether a financial literacy intervention (Rule of 72 + framing rhetoric) improves compounding knowledge and financial decision-making. Experiment A has 4 arms (Control, Full, Rule72-only, Rhetoric-only); Experiment B has 2 arms (Control, Full). Main claims: (1) treatment improves compounding test scores; (2) treatment improves financial competence (reduces valuation errors between simple vs complex frames). Data is observation-level (subject x price-list), with multiple observations per subject. SE clustered at individual (id) level. Two baseline groups map to the paper's two headline claims.

design_audit.notes: Experiment A: 4-arm RCT. Baseline spec regresses score_compounding on Full treatment dummy for Full vs Control subjects. Individual-level outcome, one obs per subject (tag==1 filter). SE clustered at id.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Compounding knowledge (score on 5 compounding test questions, 0-5 scale)
claim_object.treatment_concept: Full financial literacy intervention (Rule of 72 heuristic + framing rhetoric video)
claim_object.estimand_concept: ITT effect of full treatment on compounding test score (Full vs Control)

baseline_specs.label: Table4-Col1-ExpA
baseline_specs.notes: reg score_compounding Full if tag == 1 & (Full == 1 | Control == 1) & sample == 'old', cl(id). Note: multi == 0 is applied globally in data management before table regressions; all observations in the managed dataset are single-switchers.

constraints.notes: Baseline has 0 controls. Paper's Table D.2 (demoControl) uses full demographic control set (32 vars). Control-count envelope spans 0 to 32. Demographic controls are all pre-treatment.

canonical.notes: Cluster-robust SE at the individual level, matching the paper's cl(id).

variants.notes: Heteroskedasticity-robust (HC1) without clustering. Individual-level outcome so clustering at id should not matter much.
HC3 standard errors (jackknife-based, conservative for small samples).

budgets.notes: Individual-level outcomes with straightforward OLS. Moderate budget.

sampling.notes: Controls are demographic variables. Rather than combinatorial sampling, we define curated sets (minimal, extended, full) that mirror the paper's own approach.

diagnostics_plan.notes: Balance table across treatment arms (Table D.1 in paper).

design_audit.unit_of_observation: observation-level (subject x price-list pair), multiple obs per subject
design_audit.notes: Experiment A: 4-arm RCT (primary baseline). Additional Exp B baseline uses 2 arms (contNew, fullNew). Baseline spec regresses negAbsDiff on treatment group dummies (Control, Full, Rule72, Rhetoric) with no constant for Full vs Control comparison, observation-level data. This is the paper's main behavioral competence measure (Table 7). Data has multiple obs per subject (different price lists / amounts / delays), so clustering at id is essential. Note: multi == 0 is applied globally before table regressions.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Financial competence: negative absolute valuation difference between complex (interest-bearing) and simple frames, |discount_framed - discount_unframed|
claim_object.treatment_concept: Full financial literacy intervention (Rule of 72 heuristic + framing rhetoric video)
claim_object.estimand_concept: ITT effect of full treatment on reducing valuation errors (Full vs Control), measured as improvement in -|diff|

baseline_specs.label: Table7-Col1-ExpA
baseline_specs.notes: reg negAbsDiff Control Full Rule72 Rhetoric if sample == 'old', nocons cl(id). Key test: Full == Control. negAbsDiff = -absDiff = -abs(discount_framed - discount_unframed). Note: multi == 0 is applied globally in data management (keep if multi == 0, analysis.do line 107) before all table regressions; it is not a per-regression filter.

constraints.notes: Baseline has 0 controls. Table D.2 adds full demographic controls (32 vars). Observation-level data with clustering.

canonical.notes: Cluster-robust SE at the individual level, matching the paper's cl(id). Essential because multiple obs per subject.

variants.notes: Heteroskedasticity-robust (HC1) without clustering. For comparison; likely understates uncertainty.

budgets.notes: Observation-level data with more outcome/sample variants than G1. Slightly larger budget.

sampling.notes: Controls are demographic variables. Curated sets (minimal, extended, full) mirror the paper's approach in Table D.2.

diagnostics_plan.notes: Balance table across treatment arms (Table D.1 in paper).
Attrition rates by treatment arm. Paper notes 1 subject in Treatment and 1 in Control attrited.
